sense.name: produce, profit, or give forth as a result
sense.examples: These fields yield good crops. The research has yielded some interesting results. Our efforts yielded $156 million in emergency AIDS funding. Go with an an investment that yields high percentages. These bonds yield up to 8 percent.

sense.name: end resistance, surrender control or possession
sense.commentary: Syntax is: NP1 YIELD[transitive] NOTE: Physical and metaphorical use. Includes: YIELD UP
sense.examples: The window was painted shut and wouldn't yield. He eventually yielded control of the company to his daughter. The commander finally yielded after a long siege. She refused to yield despite our pleas. I yield to your argument that 1897 was the correct date. We will not yield to tantrums.

sense.name: move over, replace, let another pass
sense.examples: He yield his seat to a pregnant woman. Yield to the traffic on the right. Older houses and gardens were gradually yielding to modern apartments.
